awd_titl_txt: REU Site: American Student Placements and Internships in Rehabilitation Engineering (ASPIRE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Rehabilitation engineering employs a systematic approach to the design, modification, customization and/or fabrication of assistive technology for persons with disabilities. Research efforts in rehabilitation engineering are focused on identifying and addressing problems critical to achieving and maintaining the highest possible level of function in areas related to mobility, communications, sensory (e.g., hearing, tactile, vision), and cognition and in activities associated with employment, independent living, and education. With a research focus on rehabilitation engineering, this ASPIRE REU program hosted by the Human Engineering Research Laboratories (HERL) in the University of Pittsburgh is to provide an exemplary mentoring and resourceful environment that enables undergraduate students to 1) transition from dependent to independent thinkers, 2) develop a sense of excitement about entering an engineering or technical field and 3) be well prepared for their future careers. 

In this REU program, recruitment initiatives emphasize minorities and students with disabilities. Additionally, students who come from institutions with limited research opportunities will receive special consideration. Seminars, workshops, and field trips supplement the educational experience outside of the laboratories. Students in this REU Site are an active participant of a multi-disciplinary research team and acquire ownership of part of a larger-scale or pilot research project. Improving the quality of life for individuals with disabilities (Iw/D) is central to the mission of HERL, and this REU offers a unique and supportive environment for developing future research scientists and engineers. The REU experience allows participants to learn from experienced researchers and talented clinicians. These interactions will help them develop their own research skills and carry out future research topics that are important to the large population of Iw/D. HERL's research development objectives will deepen student's understanding related to rehabilitation robotics design, human-robot interaction, and technology transfer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The American Student Placements and Internships in Rehabilitation Engineering (ASPIRE) research experience for undergraduates offers an unparalleled opportunity for students pursuing engineering or technical degrees. This program enables participants to engage in experiential learning within a world-class environment, collaborating with leading mentors in the field of rehabilitation engineering. Beyond the intrinsic societal contributions, the ASPIRE program serves as a dynamic platform for learning engineering and technology in a collaborative team setting, aiming to enhance the lives of individuals and foster inclusivity. ASPIRE's home within the Human Engineering Research Laboratories (HERL) exemplifies a convergence-based approach to research, development, and invention. The interdisciplinary team, comprising engineers, clinicians, scientists, and business professionals, creates a vibrant learning environment. Importantly, the inclusion of individuals with disabilities and veterans within the team enriches the ASPIRE experience, providing interns with valuable insights from lived experiences. The program not only lays the foundation for participants to evolve as leaders but also nurtures their passion and knowledge in their chosen fields, thereby influencing their professional trajectories. Students learned how to prepare and present - "Elevator Pitch", "Scientific/Technical Paper", and "Scientific/Technical Poster". All students presented their poster at the HERL "Open House and Research Symposium", which included members of the public, academic community, engineer/scientific community, and government leaders. HERL and the NSF-ASPIRE REU have gained recognition as leaders in rehabilitation technology, engineering, and accessibility. Over the years, ASPIRE has actively fostered partnerships with local and national organizations to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in engineering and health sciences.

Some noteworthy achievements include:

The ASPIRE Program has been used as a model to establish similar programs within the Department of Veterans Affairs Office of Research and Development, leading to ten programs across the USA.

Dr. Cooper, leader of ASPIRE, received the National Medal of Technology and Innovation from the U.S. President for his groundbreaking work in empowering millions of Americans through innovative wheelchair technologies and mobility devices. His induction into the National Inventors Hall of Fame further highlights his contributions.

ASPIRE forged a meaningful partnership with Scouting USA (Boy Scouts of America - BSA), allowing students to share their knowledge and contribute to educational initiatives, such as the Invention Merit Badge.

ASPIRE students acquired valuable convergence research skills and participated in a Symposium, showcasing their achievements to leaders from government, academia, and the not-for-profit sectors. The program also facilitated enduring connections among students to advance their academic and professional growth.

ASPIRE REU students collaborated on transformative projects, including the creation of an educational board game addressing transportation barriers for individuals with long-term impairments and conducting the first-ever study estimating the number of inventors with disabilities through a survey distributed to 5,000 U.S. patent holders. ASPIRE REU students have contributed to scientific manuscripts and invention disclosures.

A collaboration with the U.S. Invention Convention and the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) was established to educate young inventors about rehabilitation engineering. Dr. Cooper's involvement as a presenter and judge in student competitions, including "Camp Invention" organized by the National Inventors Hall of Fame, further strengthened this collaboration.
